list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Letfffandgggbe functions such thatg(x)=3f(x−2)+1g(x) = 3f(x-2)+1g(x)=3f(x−2)+1, forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.The graph ofgggis obtained from the graph offffafter the following
transformations:a vertical stretch by a factor ofk, followed bya horizontal translation ofaunits, followed bya vertical translation ofbunits.\begin{aligned}
&\text{a vertical stretch by a factor of $k$, followed by} \\
&\text{a horizontal translation of $a$ units, followed by} \\
&\text{a vertical translation of $b$ units}. \\
\end{aligned}​a vertical stretch by a factor ofk, followed bya horizontal translation ofaunits, followed bya vertical translation ofbunits.​Write down the value of:kkk;aaa;bbb.[3]Leth(x)=−2g(x)h(x) = -2g(x)h(x)=−2g(x), forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.The point P(3,4)(3,4)(3,4)on the graph ofgggis mapped to point Q on the graph
ofhhh.Find the coordinates of Q.[3]
list.markScheme:
k=3\answer{k = 3}k=3​a=2\answer{a = 2}a=2​b=1\answer{b = 1}b=1​The graph ofhhhis obtained from the graph ofgggusing two
transformations.Their geometric descriptions are:transformation1:vertical stretch by a factor of2;transformation2:reflection in thex-axis.\begin{aligned}
\text{transformation $1$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\text{vertical stretch by a factor of $2$;} \\[6pt]
\text{transformation $2$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\text{reflection in the $x$-axis.}\end{aligned}transformation 1:transformation 2:​vertical stretch by a factor of 2;reflection in thex-axis.​If we apply the transformations111and222to P, we find

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/81adf7f8-647c-479f-bd0f-8f896cd0c7c3/images/fe8c659b-613c-4fc0-a165-b07d10509323/1510a052325892668888784527ddbb81323a45d9.svg)

Hence the coordinates of Q are(3,−8)\answer{(3,-8)}(3,−8)​

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
The following diagram shows the graph ofy=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x), for−1≤x≤2-1 \leq x \leq 2−1≤x≤2.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8407806b-3c8d-4f8a-ba57-52619272880d/images/ee08b3c6-49a0-41f7-814f-bb4d9079b11c/ccc9d5942ccfefc2e6313a34922fed1ada13594f.svg)

Write down the value of:f(1)f(1)f(1);f−1(−2)f^{-1}(-2)f−1(−2).[2]Find(f∘f)(1)(f\circ f)(1)(f∘f)(1).[2]Sketch the graph ofy=f(−x)y = f(-x)y=f(−x)on the same grid above.[2]
list.markScheme:
f(1)=2\answer{f(1) = 2}f(1)=2​f−1(−2)=−1\answer{f^{-1}(-2) = -1}f−1(−2)=−1​We have(f∘f)(1)=f(f(1))=f(2)=6\begin{aligned}
(f\circ f)(1) &= f(f(1)) \\[6pt]
&= f(2) \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 6}\end{aligned}(f∘f)(1)​=f(f(1))=f(2)=6​​The graph ofy=f(−x)y = f(-x)y=f(−x)is a reflection of the graph ofy=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x)in theyyy-axis.Hence, if we sketch the graph ofy=f(−x)y = f(-x)y=f(−x)on the same grid below,
we have

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8407806b-3c8d-4f8a-ba57-52619272880d/images/64f14811-163b-49f4-8bcc-e95f5b9a1d96/d2b3518aa3484d1ffd19b0a1dd3f20d6f92c6046.svg)

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Letf(x)=x3f(x) = x^3f(x)=x3andg(x)=5(x−2)3g(x) = 5(x-2)^3g(x)=5(x−2)3, forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.The graph ofgggcan be obtained from the graph offffusing two transformations.Give a full geometric description of each of the transformations.[2]The graph ofgggis translated by 4 units in the direction of the positivexxx-axis, and 1 unit in the direction of the negativeyyy-axis to give the graph of a
functionhhh.The point P(1,1)(1,1)(1,1)on the graph offffis translated to point Q on the
graph ofhhh.Find the coordinates of Q.[4]
list.markScheme:
We havetransformation1:vertical stretch by a factor of5transformation2:translation of 2 units in the direction of the positivex-axis.\begin{aligned}
\text{transformation $1$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{vertical stretch by a factor of $5$}} \\[6pt]
\text{transformation $2$}: &\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{translation of 2 units in the direction of the positive $x$-axis.}}\end{aligned}transformation 1:transformation 2:​vertical stretch by a factor of 5​translation of 2 units in the direction of the positivex-axis.​​If we apply the transformations111and222from part (a), and transformation333from part (b) to P, we find

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e1a61284-0cae-4301-9a9e-89a7e58d9d56/images/b28c508c-6131-4aee-a6fd-a87b131e9f21/577066d1f46b6880207621796d732b7e8ac43d46.svg)

Hence the coordinates of Q are(7,4)\answer{(7,4)}(7,4)​

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Letf(x)=0.2ex+2−4f(x) = 0.2e^{x+2} - 4f(x)=0.2ex+2−4, for−3≤x≤2-3 \leq x \leq 2−3≤x≤2.On the following grid, sketch the graph ofy=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x).[3]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/4d1c7bf9-8d2a-4f7a-945e-f582b73039b2/219ede634589aee775d4d590dd79b30ff5c63914.svg)

Find the coordinates of:thexxx-intercept;theyyy-intercept.[2]The graph offffis reflected in thexxx-axis, then translated 1 unit in the direction of the positivexxx-axis and 2 units in the direction of the positiveyyy-axis to obtain the graph of a functionggg.Findg(x)g(x)g(x).[2]
list.markScheme:
If we draw the graph ofy=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x)for−3≤x≤2-3 \leq x \leq 2−3≤x≤2[by using
G.D.C.], we have

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/0c8cb343-6319-4c4b-bd01-6881dfb5c2ff/a0ce7feb5a9182c2d088b3711cfba75a324b8033.svg)

Solving the equationf(x)=0f(x) = 0f(x)=0forxxx, we have0.2ex+2−4=0x≈0.996[by using G.D.C.]\begin{aligned}
\hspace{3.2em} 0.2e^{x+2} - 4 &= 0 \\[6pt]
x &\approx 0.996 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}0.2ex+2−4x​=0≈0.996[by using G.D.C.]​Hence the coordinates of thexxx-intercept are(0.996,0)\answer{(0.996,0)}(0.996,0)​Evaluatingy=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x)forx=0x = 0x=0, we havey=f(0)=0.2e0+2−4≈−2.52\begin{aligned}
y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
&= 0.2e^{0+2} - 4 \hspace{0.4em} \\[7pt]
&\approx -2.52\end{aligned}y​=f(0)=0.2e0+2−4≈−2.52​Hence the coordinates of theyyy-intercept are(0,−2.52)\answer{(0,-2.52)}(0,−2.52)​We haveg(x)=−f(x−1)+2=−[0.2e(x−1)+2−4]+2=−0.2ex+1+6\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.5em} g(x) &= -f(x-1) + 2 \\[6pt]
&= -\big[0.2e^{(x-1)+2} - 4\big] + 2 \\[6pt]
&\answer{= -0.2e^{x+1} + 6}\end{aligned}g(x)​=−f(x−1)+2=−[0.2e(x−1)+2−4]+2=−0.2ex+1+6​​

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Letf(t)=3t2+27f(t) = 3t^2 + 27f(t)=3t2+27, wheret>0t > 0t>0.The graph of a functiongggis obtained when the graph offffis
transformed bya stretch by a scale of19parallel to they-axis, followed bya horizontal translation of 4 and a vertical translation of -5\begin{aligned}
&\text{a stretch by a scale of\hspace{0.05em} $\dfrac{1}{9}$ \hspace{0.05em}parallel to the $y$-axis, followed by} \\
&\text{a horizontal translation of 4 and a vertical translation of -5}\\
\end{aligned}​a stretch by a scale of91​parallel to they-axis, followed bya horizontal translation of 4 and a vertical translation of -5​Findg(t)g(t)g(t), giving your answer in the forma(t−b)2+ca(t - b)^2 + ca(t−b)2+c.[4]A particle moves along a straight line so that its velocity in
m s−1^{-1}−1, at timetttseconds, is given byg(t)g(t)g(t).Find the distance the particle travels betweent=7t = 7t=7andt=10t = 10t=10.[3]
list.markScheme:
We haveg(t)=19f(t−4)−5=19[3(t−4)2+27]−5=13(t−4)2−2\begin{aligned}
\hspace{3em} g(t) &= \dfrac{1}{9}f(t - 4) - 5  \\[6pt]
&= \dfrac{1}{9}\big[3(t - 4)^2 + 27\big] - 5 \\[6pt]
&\answer{= \dfrac{1}{3}(t - 4)^2 -2}\end{aligned}g(t)​=91​f(t−4)−5=91​[3(t−4)2+27]−5=31​(t−4)2−2​​The distance the particle travels betweent=7t = 7t=7andt=10t = 10t=10isdistance=∫710∣g(t)∣dt=∫710∣13(t−4)2−2∣dt=15m[by using G.D.C.]\begin{aligned}
\hspace{4.8em} \text{distance} &= \int_7^{10} \left|g(t)\right| \mathrm{d}t \\[2pt]
&= \int_7^{10} \left|\dfrac{1}{3}(t - 4)^2 -2\right| \mathrm{d}t \\[9pt]
&\answer{= 15 \text{ m}}  \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}distance​=∫710​∣g(t)∣dt=∫710​​31​(t−4)2−2​dt=15m​[by using G.D.C.]​

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Considerf(x)=2cos⁡(x−π2)+3f(x)=2\cos\left(x-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+3f(x)=2cos(x−2π​)+3andg(x)=4cos⁡(x+π2)+2g(x)=4\cos\left(x+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+2g(x)=4cos(x+2π​)+2.The functionfffis mapped ontogggby three transformations.Fully describe each of the transformations and the order in which they must be applied.[3]A new function is such thath(x)=g(x)+kh(x)=g(x)+kh(x)=g(x)+kwherek∈Rk \in \mathbb{R}k∈R.Find the minimum value ofkkksuch thath(x)≥0h(x) \geq 0h(x)≥0for allxxx.[2]

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Consider the functionsf(x)=3cos⁡(x)+92f(x)=3\cos(x)+\dfrac{9}{2}f(x)=3cos(x)+29​andg(x)=3cos⁡(x+π3)+Ag(x)=3\cos\left(x+\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right)+Ag(x)=3cos(x+3π​)+A, wherex∈Rx\in \mathbb{R}x∈RandA<92A< \dfrac{9}{2}A<29​.Describe a sequence of two transformations that transforms the graph offffto the graph ofggg.[3]Theyyy-intercept of the graphgggis at the point(0,92)\left(0\,,\dfrac{9}{2}\right)(0,29​)Find the range ofggg.[4]

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
[Maximum marks: 10]The functionf(x)=asin⁡(bx)+cf(x)=a\sin{(bx)}+cf(x)=asin(bx)+cwhere0≤x≤π0 \leq x \leq \pi0≤x≤πanda,b,c∈Ra,b,c \in \mathrm{R}a,b,c∈Ris shown below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/0547420d-b08d-4f9e-bd37-d903d3be790b/AA1154.JPEG)

The coordinates of the first two stationary points are(π6,−1)(\tfrac{\pi}{6}, -1)(6π​,−1)and(π2,3)(\tfrac{\pi}{2},3)(2π​,3)respectively.Finda.c.b.[5]The domain off(x)f(x)f(x)is restricted toπ2≤x≤k\tfrac{\pi}{2}\leq x \leq k2π​≤x≤k, wherek∈Rk \in \mathrm{R}k∈R. This restriction allows an inverse to exist.Find the largest possible value ofkkk.[2]Another function is defined asg(x)=−2f(12x)+3g(x)=-2f(\tfrac{1}{2}x)+3g(x)=−2f(21​x)+3.Determine the coordinates of thefirstmaximum value ofg(x)g(x)g(x).[3]

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Letf(x)=3x2+12x+9f(x) = 3x^2 + 12x + 9f(x)=3x2+12x+9, forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.For the graph offff, find:theyyy-intercept;thexxx-intercepts.[4]The functionfffcan be written in the formf(x)=a(x−h)2+kf(x) = a(x-h)^2+kf(x)=a(x−h)2+k.Find the values ofaaa,hhhandkkk.[5]For the graph offff, write down:the coordinates of the vertex;the equation of the axis of symmetry.[2]The graph of a functiongggis obtained from the graph offffby a reflection in thexxx-axis, followed by a translation of 4 units in the direction of the positiveyyyaxis.Findg(x)g(x)g(x), giving your answer in the formg(x)=px2+qx+rg(x) = px^2 + qx + rg(x)=px2+qx+r.[4]
list.markScheme:
Evaluatingf(x)=3x2+12x+9f(x) = 3x^2 + 12x + 9f(x)=3x2+12x+9forx=0x = 0x=0, we havef(0)=3(0)2+12(0)+9=9\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5em} f(0) &= 3(0)^2 + 12(0) + 9 \\[6pt]
&= 9 \end{aligned}f(0)​=3(0)2+12(0)+9=9​Hence theyyy-intercept isA(0,9)\answer{\mathrm{A}(0,9)}A(0,9)​Solving the equationf(x)=0f(x) = 0f(x)=0forxxx, we have3x2+12x+9=0x2+4x+3=0(x+3)(x+1)=0x=−3,−1\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.5em} 3x^2 + 12x + 9 &= 0 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
x^2 + 4x + 3 &= 0 \\[7pt]
(x+3)(x+1) &= 0 \\[7pt]
x &= -3,\hspace{0.25em}-1 \\
\end{aligned}3x2+12x+9x2+4x+3(x+3)(x+1)x​=0=0=0=−3,−1​Hence thexxx-intercepts areB(−3,0)\answer{\mathrm{B}(-3,0)}B(−3,0)​andC(−1,0)\answer{\mathrm{C}(-1,0)}C(−1,0)​Using the method of completing the square, we havef(x)=3x2+12x+9=3[x2+4x]+9=3[(x+2)2−4]+9=3(x+2)2−3\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.9em} f(x) &= 3x^2 + 12x + 9 \\[6pt]
&= 3\big[x^2 + 4x\big] + 9 \\[6pt]
&= 3\big[(x + 2)^2 - 4\big] + 9 \\[6pt]
&= 3(x + 2)^2 - 3 \\
\end{aligned}f(x)​=3x2+12x+9=3[x2+4x]+9=3[(x+2)2−4]+9=3(x+2)2−3​Hence we finda=3,h=−2\answer{a = 3,\hspace{0.25em} h = -2}a=3,h=−2​andk=−3\answer{k = -3}k=−3​(−2,−3)\answer{(-2,-3)}(−2,−3)​x=−2\answer{x = -2}x=−2​We haveg(x)=−f(x)+4=−(3x2+12x+9)+4=−3x2−12x−5\begin{aligned}
\hspace{4em} g(x) &= -f(x)+4 \\[6pt]
&= -(3x^2 + 12x + 9)+4 \\[6pt]
&\answer{= -3x^2 - 12x - 5}\end{aligned}g(x)​=−f(x)+4=−(3x2+12x+9)+4=−3x2−12x−5​​

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Letf(x)=2x2+4x+pf(x) = 2x^2 + 4x + pf(x)=2x2+4x+p, forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R, wherep∈Zp \in \mathbb{Z}p∈Z.The equationf(x)=0f(x) = 0f(x)=0has two equal roots.Write down the value of the discriminant offff.Show thatp=2p = 2p=2.[3]For the graph offff, find:the equation of the axis of symmetry.the coordinates of the vertex;[4]Write down the solution to the equationf(x)=0f(x) = 0f(x)=0.[1]The functionfffcan be written in the formf(x)=a(x−h)2+kf(x) = a(x-h)^2 + kf(x)=a(x−h)2+k.
Findthe values ofaaa,hhhandkkk.[5]The graph of a functiongggis obtained from the graph offffby a
reflectionin thexxx-axis. Find the coordinates of the vertex of the graph ofggg.[2]
list.markScheme:
△=0\answer{\triangle  = 0}△=0​We have△=b2−4ac0=42−4(2)(p)0=16−8p16=8p\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} \triangle  &= b^2 - 4ac \\[4pt]
0 &= 4^2 - 4(2)(p) \hspace{0.5em} \\[5pt]
0 &= 16 - 8p \\[5pt]
16 &= 8p \\
\end{aligned}△0016​=b2−4ac=42−4(2)(p)=16−8p=8p​p=2\answer{p = 2} \hspace{2.9em}p=2​Using the axis of symmetry formula, we getx=−b2ax=−42(2)\begin{aligned}
x &= -\dfrac{b}{2a} \\[6pt]
x &= -\dfrac{4}{2(2)} \hspace{1.4em} \\
\end{aligned}xx​=−2ab​=−2(2)4​​x=−1\answer{x = -1} \hspace{2.9em}x=−1​Evaluatingf(x)=2x2+4x+2f(x)=2x^2 + 4x + 2f(x)=2x2+4x+2forx=−1x = -1x=−1, we havef(−1)=2(−1)2+4(−1)+2=0\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.2em} f(-1) &= 2(-1)^2 + 4(-1) + 2 \\[8pt]
&= 0\end{aligned}f(−1)​=2(−1)2+4(−1)+2=0​Hence the coordinates of the vertex are(−1,0)\answer{(-1,0)}(−1,0)​x=−1\answer{x=-1}x=−1​Using the method of completing the square, we havef(x)=2x2+4x+2=2[x2+2x]+2=2[(x+1)2−1]+2=2(x+1)2\begin{aligned}
\hspace{3em} f(x) &= 2x^2 + 4x + 2 \\[6pt]
&= 2\big[x^2 + 2x\big] + 2 \\[6pt]
&= 2\big[(x+1)^2 - 1\big] + 2 \\[6pt]
&= 2(x+1)^2\end{aligned}f(x)​=2x2+4x+2=2[x2+2x]+2=2[(x+1)2−1]+2=2(x+1)2​Hence we finda=2,h=−1\answer{a = 2,\hspace{0.25em} h = -1}a=2,h=−1​andk=0\answer{k = 0}k=0​We haveg(x)=−f(x)=−2(x+1)2\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.2em}  g(x) &= -f(x) \\[6pt]
&= -2(x+1)^2\end{aligned}g(x)​=−f(x)=−2(x+1)2​Hence the coordinates of the vertex of
the graph ofgggare(−1,0)\answer{(-1,0)}(−1,0)​

list.title: Question 11
list.markScheme:
We havef(x)=2(x−1)2−8=2(x2−2x+1)−8=2x2−4x−6\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.9em} f(x) &= 2(x-1)^2-8 \\[6pt] 
&= 2(x^2-2x+1)-8 \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 2x^2-4x-6}\end{aligned}f(x)​=2(x−1)2−8=2(x2−2x+1)−8=2x2−4x−6​​(1,−8)\answer{(1,-8)}(1,−8)​P(0,−6)\answer{\text{P}(0,-6)}P(0,−6)​Solving the equationf(x)=0f(x) = 0f(x)=0forxxx, we have2x2−4x−6=0x2−2x−3=0(x+1)(x−3)=0x=−1,3\begin{aligned}
2x^2-4x-6 &= 0 \\[6pt]
x^2-2x-3 &= 0 \\[6pt]
\hspace{0.8em} (x+1)(x-3) &= 0 \\[6pt]
x &= -1,\hspace{0.25em}3\end{aligned}2x2−4x−6x2−2x−3(x+1)(x−3)x​=0=0=0=−1,3​Hence thexxx-intercepts
areA(−1,0)\answer{\text{A}(-1,0)}A(−1,0)​andB(3,0)\answer{\text{B}(3,0)}B(3,0)​If we sketch the graph offff, we have

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/defd40b3-8635-4c03-88d0-1ea05c7ccca1/images/42674bdd-229f-43b4-bb47-2584f965f100/8374016b8a888aa9fc9466667cfab6ca4babdde2.svg)

We havef(x)=ag(x−h)+k2(x−1)2−8=a[6(x−h)2]+k2(x−1)2−8=6a(x−h)2+k\begin{aligned}
f(x) &= ag(x-h)+k \\[6pt]
2(x-1)^2 - 8 &= a\big[6(x-h)^2\big]+k \\[6pt]
2(x-1)^2 - 8 &= 6a(x-h)^2+k \hspace{2.5em}\end{aligned}f(x)2(x−1)2−82(x−1)2−8​=ag(x−h)+k=a[6(x−h)2]+k=6a(x−h)2+k​Hence we
finda=1/3,h=1\answer{a = 1/3,\hspace{0.25em} h = 1}a=1/3,h=1​andk=−8\answer{k = -8}k=−8​

list.title: Question 12
list.content: Letf(x)=2x2−8x+6f(x) = 2x^2-8x+6f(x)=2x2−8x+6, forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.Write down the value off(0)f(0)f(0).[1]Solve the equationf(x)=0f(x) = 0f(x)=0.[3]The functionfffcan be written in the formf(x)=a(x−h)2+kf(x) = a(x-h)^2+kf(x)=a(x−h)2+k.Find the values ofaaa,hhhandkkk.[5]For the graph offff, write down:the coordinates of the vertex;the equation of the axis of symmetry.[2]The graph of a functiongggis obtained from the graph offffby a reflection in thexxx-axis, followed by a translation of 1 unit to the right and 3 units up.Findg(x)g(x)g(x), giving your answer in the formg(x)=px2+qx+rg(x) = px^2+qx+rg(x)=px2+qx+r.[4]

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Letf(x)=a(x+1)(x+5)f(x) = a(x+1)(x+5)f(x)=a(x+1)(x+5), forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R, wherea∈Za \in \mathbb{Z}a∈Z. The following diagram shows part of the graph offff.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b2539ad3-5cb1-47b4-82fb-0f17c7d9b8b2/images/5a0794f4-b904-4254-9ade-c72ff4d130c0/c560b93b90031104353dd8752d2c6976f60f1751.svg)
